g.text: 1999). After further considering the systematic dry bias, the
cating a negligible increase of future summer precipitation over
the CUS. We believe that the adjusted projections are more
credible than the default projections considering the large
inherent model systematic bias over this region. This can have
important implications for appropriate decision makings and
To conclude, most climate models suffer from systematic
biases. This work aims to better understand the cause of the
warm/dry bias over the CUS during summertime, which is highly
coherent among the latest GCMs. Our investigation suggests that
ed warm/dry bias is likely triggered by the
the large precipitation events, followed by strong and complex
atmosphere interactions on different time scales. Other
ciencies, such as underestimated shallow cumulus and
misrepresented soil processes, may also initiate or reinforce the
warm and dry bias, but the de
events in models is at least one of the leading causes of the bias.
. All scatter plots in this study are
tted using linear functions in a least-
square sense to assess the dependence of
. The cooling effect on temperature of individual rainfall event is
compared within a week under three different rainfall intensities, i.e., daily rainfall
10 mm but larger than 1 mm, and daily rainfall
less than 1 mm but larger than 0.1 mm, respectively. The decrease in temperature is
calculated with respect to the day prior to the rainfall event.
consecutive non-precipitating days following a rainfall event (with daily rainfall
1 mm). The dry precondition composite requires
ve consecutive non-precipitating days in each composite are used to cal-
ve consecutive non-precipitation days in dry
precondition are selected to minimize the in
uence of a preceding rainfall event in
consideration of the soil could impact the land
between 4 and 8 days after a rainfall event
. The correction for the temperature change is straightforward.
Once we have the scaling factor, we simply subtract the correction term, i.e., model
historical bias times the scaling factor (the slope in Fig. 5), from the model original
projected warming for each model. Correction for precipitation here is based on
the correspondence of temperature bias and precipitation bias identi
For each model, precipitation correction term is calculated from the linear equa-
is the bias correction term for the future
scenario. And similarly, these correction terms are added to the model original
projected change of precipitation to get the corrected precipitation change.
. All the plots in this study are made using NCAR Command
Language (NCL; http://www.ncl.ucar.edu/). The data sets and scripts generated are
available from the corresponding author upon request.
. Monthly near-surface air temperature and precipitation data
from 19 models contributing to the CMIP5
details, http://pcmdi9.llnl.gov), including simulations of historical run (1850
and three Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios (2006
Among them, 15 models also provide daily precipitation. All data have been lin-
early interpolated to a native 1°×1° latitude-longitude grid (~100-km spatial
resolution), and monthly means are computed over a box centered over the central
U.S. (see Fig. 1 for the location of the box). We use the Global Precipitation
piled Climate Research Unit (CRU; http://www.cru.uea.ac.uk/data) Version 3.23
2005 for the comparison with the historical
W) provides vast variables at hourly frequencies. Vari-
ables, including cloud fraction, surface downward and upward radiant
uxes, precipitation, and surface meteorology such as
temperature, and relative humidity from ARMBE data sets during 1996

climate model using a weather forecasting approach.
